lines.text:
[Has overheard Manning's selfish deal]
Tell ya what Dave. You find yourself out there in the middle of a fire fight, with your guts hanging out, screaming for a medic, if I can help you without endangering my own life, I won't hesitate.
If I can help you in any way without endangering my own life, I won't hesitate. But I'm not taking a bullet for anybody!
That's not good enough.
That's as good as it gets.
Captain Pritchett sir? You have a Private Manning here.
Alright
[Looks at Manning]
You Manning?
I think so.
Give him a straight answer Private.
Relax!
[Turns back to Manning]
You can stop looking for your platoon. They didn't make it.
What?
Looks like you were the only one who made it out. Your lucky day.

[Sarcastic]
Lucky day?
You're alive.
Am I?

You know it's amazing really when you stop to think about it. Whole platoon fingers its way into the Factory and one guy makes it out to talk about it. You got twenty-five or thirty guys dead or dying and you walk out without a scratch on you.
It's my lucky day.
Yeah lucky. That's one way of looking at it.
But not the only way, right Talbot?
There isn't anything sacred with you, is there Manning?
Warm dry feet.
How'd you manage to get out Manning? Did you get cut off from the rest of your platoon? Trees get pretty thick out there? Did you get lost? Come on, what happened?
You got something in that vat of yours, just spill it.

Alright. Look it's like this. See, your routine isn't as seamless as you think it is. Always hanging back a little bit, never volunteering. Doing just enough to keep out of trouble, but never enough to really help out.

[Sarcastic]
I'm kind of an emotional guy.

[Grabs Manning's shoulder]
Get one thing fucking straight, man. There is no hang-back now. You got a glob of greenies looking at you to keep 'em alive and if I find out that one of them answers the last muster because of your yellow streak, I will personally put a bullet in your brain.
[last lines]
[Pvt. Sanderson is carrying David on his back, mortally wounded after the final battle, mirroring the movie's opening scene]
I'm not gonna make it. I'm losing too much blood.
You're gonna make it. You're gonna owe me big, lieutenant.
I'm gonna owe you shit.
Less than a mile, in less than a mile.
It's too far.
It's not too far.
[David lets out a sad, disheartened laugh]
What's so funny?
...You.
You mean what?
Forget it.
I'm taking you home, Dave.
Sure.
You're going home.
[David loses consciousness as the two go off into the distance]
nobody dies.
You smile at me again, and I'll kick your teeth out!

[about his wound]
It hurts... Don't pick me up anymore.
Listen Bob, if I leave you, ain't nobody gonna find you. You're gonna die out here.
Just sit here for a bit.
[after a pause]
I AM dying.

[evasively]
We can't sit here.

[has just shot one of his own troops in order to hide their position]
Go! Go, Sanderson!

[the new troops are lounging around]
Hey dude, give me that cigarette!

[pulls his pants down and places the cigarette near his rear end]
See, only ass holes smoke!
Listen, I'm getting the hell out of here. I've done my share, and I'm getting out!
Congratulations Private, you're a sergeant now.
I am absolutely the wrong man!
that's something the rest of your platoon couldn't do. Call me crazy, but from where I'm standing, that qualifies you for the job!
What's your name?
Warren.
Welcome to the death factory, Warren.

[carrying his wounded comrade]
You're gonna make it! You can do this!
I'm through with this. I'm getting out as soon as I can.

[Hands Capt. Zenek the dog tags of Lt. Lukas' platoon]
You wanted to know the status of his platoon?
Just a minute soldier, you're treading dangerously close to a court-martial!
That gets me out of here, right... sir?
You're Manning aren't you?
What do you care?
Baxter!
No! No fucking way, no fucking way, no fucking way!
Get up there, Baxter!
Goddamn you, stick with it, Bobby! Fucking dig in, Bobby! Come on, whose tough as nails?
Me, sir.
That's right, you're tough. Tough as what?
Nails.
That's right, now you say it.
Tough as nails!
You're goddamn right, you're tough as nails!
[first lines]

August 1944. The outcome of the Second World War appeared to be no longer in doubt. Paris was liberated. After four years of fighting, victory against the Germans seemed assured. Since the Normandy landings, American and Allied forces had battled their way across northern Europe, and pushed the German enemy to within its own homeland.

[Instructing new recruit]
You don't think about it, you don't hesitate, you just do it, you understand? Otherwise, you're gonna go home to your mama in a box, alright?
What is your name?
Doug... Despin.
Well, Doug Despin, this is the second time I'm telling you to shut up.

[Through the walkie-talkie]
You hold that bridge Captain! That's an order!
I've already lost thirty men!
This isn't a debate, Pritchett! You hold that goddamn bridge!

[Screams]
This is suicide!

[Running forward in the smoke]
Manning!

[Sees a German soldier aiming his gun at Chamberlain]
No!
Where's Lt. Lukas?
How you doing, Roy?
I'm fine sir. I can stay.
I think you need a rest.
Everybody here needs a rest, sir.
Captain, this conversation was over the first time we had it and it is just as over now.

[Points gun at Manning's head]
You executed Baxter!
You're damn right I did! He ran, you'd have done the same thing!
Put the gun down, Talbot!
Shut up!
Go ahead. We're all dead anyway.

[Is being promoted against his wishes]
I was a private three days ago
This isn't up for discussion, Lieutenant. You've got no choice in this. And as it is... neither do I.

[about Manning]
If he hadn't shot Baxter, we all would've run. And we'd still be taking fire from those 88's.
[Looks at Manning]
I'll go with you.

[Stares at the carnage]
I'll be a son of a bitch!
Where's your squad?

[Points at Sanderson]
Over there.
